revision.text:
{{Year nav topic5|1530|art}} The year '''1530 in art''' involved some significant events and new works. ==Events== * September 15 – Portrait of ''[[Saint Dominic in Soriano]]'' appears in the Dominican friary at [[Soriano Calabro]], soon acquiring a reputation for having marvellous properties. ==Works== {{Infobox Artwork | image_file=Cupola Duomo Parma Correggio.jpg | title=[[Assumption of the Virgin (Correggio)|Assumption of the Virgin]] | artist=[[Antonio da Correggio]] | year=1526–1530 | type=Fresco | height_metric=1093 | width_metric=1195 | metric_unit=cm | imperial_unit=in | museum=[[Parma Cathedral]] }} * [[Bronzino]] – ''[[Portrait of Andrea Doria as Neptune]]'' (approximate date) * [[Antonio da Correggio]] ** ''[[Assumption of the Virgin (Correggio)|Assumption of the Virgin]]'' ([[fresco]] on dome of [[Parma Cathedral]] completed) ** ''[[Nativity (Correggio)|Nativity]]'' (placed in church of St. Prosper of [[Reggio Emilia]]; now in [[Gemäldegalerie Alte Meister]], [[Dresden]]) * [[Lucas Cranach the Elder]] – ''[[:File:Lucas Cranach the Elder - Judgment of Paris.jpg|The Judgement of Paris]]'' (approximate date) * [[Il Garofalo]] – ''Madonna and Child and St Jerome'' * [[Quentin Matsys]] – ''[[Ill-Matched Marriage]]'' (approximate completion date) * [[Parmigianino]] – ''Portrait of a Man Reading a Book'' (approximate date; [[York Art Gallery]], England) * [[Titian]] – ''[[The Madonna of the Rabbit]]'' (approximate date) * [[:File:Francis1-1.jpg|Portrait of Francis I of France]] (approximate date) ==Births== * [[Giovanni Battista Armenini]], Italian art historian and critic (died [[1609 in art|1609]]) * [[Nicolás Borrás]], Spanish painter (died [[1610 in art|1610]]) * [[Barthel Bruyn the Younger]], German portraitist, son of [[Barthel Bruyn the Elder]] (died [[1607 in art|1607-1610]]) * [[Francesco Camilliani]], Italian sculptor of the Renaissance period (died [[1586 in art|1586]]) * [[Cesare da Bagno]], Italian sculptor and medallist (died [[1564 in art|1564]]) * [[Giovanni Battista Fiammeri]], Florentine Jesuit painter (died [[1606 in art|1606]]) * [[Lattanzio Gambara]], Italian painter, active in Renaissance and Mannerist styles (died [[1574 in art|1574]]) * [[Aurelio Luini]], [[Italians|Italian]] painter from [[Milan]] (died [[1592 in art|1592]]) * [[Simon Pereyns]], Flemish painter who worked in Portugal, Spain, and Mexico (died [[1600 in art|1600]]) * [[Lorenzo Sabbatini]], [[Italy|Italian]] [[Painting|painter]] of the [[Renaissance]] (died [[1577 in art|1577]]) * [[Adamo Scultori]], [[Italy|Italian]] [[engraver]] (died [[1585 in art|1585]]) * [[Ercole Setti]], Italian engraver (died [[1618 in art|1618]]) * [[Hendrick van den Broeck]], Flemish painter active mainly in Rome (died [[1597 in art|1597]]) * [[Cesare Vecellio]], Italian engraver and painter (died [[1601 in art|1601]]) * [[Ottavio Semini]], Italian painter born and trained in [[Genoa]] (died [[1604 in art|1604]]) * (born c.1530-1): [[Johan Gregor van der Schardt]], Dutch-born sculptor (died c.[[1591 in art|1591]]) * (born 1530-1535): [[Niccolò Circignani]], [[Italy|Italian]] painter of the late-[[Renaissance]] or [[Mannerism|Mannerist]] period (died [[1590 in art|1590]]) ==Deaths== * February 24 – [[Properzia de' Rossi]], Italian female Renaissance sculptor (born c. [[1490 in art|1490]]) * April 28 – [[Niklaus Manuel Deutsch I|Niklaus Manuel]], Swiss dramaturg, painter, graphic artist and politician (born [[1484 in art|1484]]) * date unknown **[[Marco Basaiti]], Venetian Greek painter and a rival of Giovanni Bellini (born [[1470 in art|1470]]) **[[Quentin Matsys]], Flemish painter (born [[1466 in art|1466]]) **[[Bartolomeo Suardi]], [[Italian people|Italian]] [[painting|painter]] and [[architect]] (born [[1456 in art|1456]]) **[[Domenico Panetti]], [[Italy|Italian]] painter of the [[Renaissance]] period, active mainly in [[Ferrara]] (born [[1460 in art|1460]]) **[[Kanō Masanobu]], chief painter of the [[Ashikaga shogunate]], founder of the [[Kanō school]] of painting (born [[1434 in art|1434]]) **[[Andrea Sabbatini]], [[Italy|Italian]] [[Painting|painter]] of the [[Renaissance]] (born [[1487 in art|1487]])
[[Category:1530 in art| ]] [[Category:Years of the 16th century in art]] {{Art-hist-stub}}

page.title: A Collation of Four Important Manuscripts of the Gospels

revision.text:
{{italic title}} '''''A Collation of Four Important Manuscripts of the Gospels''''', full title: ''A Collation of Four Important Manuscripts of the Gospels: With a View to Prove Their Common Origin, and to Restore the Text of Their Archetype''. The book was published in 1877 by Thomas Kingsmill Abbott on behalf of his deceased colleague William Hugh Ferrar.
[[William Hugh Ferrar]] (1826–1871) before his death collated four [[Minuscule Greek|minuscules]] (Greek handwritten [[Lower case|cursive]] texts) to demonstrate that they shared a common provenance. The four collated minuscules are: [[Minuscule 13|13]], [[Minuscule 69|69]], [[Minuscule 124|124]], [[Minuscule 346|346]] (known as [[Family 13]] or ''Ferrar Family''). Ferrar intended to establish that these four codices are derived from a common archetype, and to exhibit as nearly as possible the actual text of this [[archetype]] of these four minuscules, a text, therefore, more ancient and authoritative than of any of these manuscripts separately.
The book was published in 1877 by [[Thomas Kingsmill Abbott|T. K. Abbott]] on behalf of William Hugh Ferrar, who had died six years previous.
; Sigla : L – codex 69 : M – 346 : P – 13 : V – 124 : S – Stephanus' text edited by [[F. H. A. Scrivener|Scrivener]] : L<sub>1</sub> – L prima manu : L<sub>2</sub> – L secunda manu
==Further reading==
*{{cite book|last=Ferrar|first=W. H.|authorlink=William Hugh Ferrar|author2=T. K Abbott|title=A Collation of Four Important Manuscripts of the Gospels by the late William Hugh Ferrar|publisher=[[Macmillan Publishers|Macmillan & Co.]]|year=1877|location=Dublin|pages=389 + LVIII}} [collates 13, 69, 124, and 346 in the Gospels]
==External links== *W. H. Ferrar, [https://archive.org/stream/collationoffouri00ferr#page/n11/mode/2up ''A Collation of Four Important Manuscripts of the Gospels''], at the Internet Archive
{{DEFAULTSORT:Collation of Four Important Manuscripts of the Gospels}} [[Category:Biblical criticism]] [[Category:1877 books]] [[Category:Books about ancient Christianity]] [[Category:Family 13]] [[Category:Books about the Bible]]

{{Cleanup|reason= not objective, poor writing style, poor grammar, poor spelling|date=March 2014}} The '''Abel Assessment for Sexual Interest''' (also '''Abel Assessment for Interest in Paraphilias''') is an assessment test that purports to measure sexual interest in various subjects – and especially to measure a tendency toward [[pedophilia]].<ref name=Chammah>{{cite web |first=Maurice |last=Chammah |url=https://www.theatlantic.com/politics/archive/2015/07/the-sex-offender-test/397850/ |title=The Sex-Offender Test: How a computerized assessment can help determine the fate of men who've been accused of sexually abusing children |work=[[The Atlantic]] |date=2015-07-09 |accessdate=2015-07-09}}</ref> The test was created by [[Gene Abel|Dr. Gene G. Abel]] in 1995, and has been subsequently revised several times. It has been used as evidence in [[Northern America]] when prosecuting [[sex offender]]s, although its reliability has since been disputed<ref>{{cite journal|title= Statistical adequacy of the Abel Assessment for Interest in Paraphilias.|date=2014-01-24 |pmid=10497779 | volume=11 |journal=Sex Abuse |pages=195–205}} (abstract only; membership required for access to full text).</ref> and it has been declared inadmissible in court in various [[jurisdiction]]s.
The Abel Assessment is controversial, because its results, although subjective, are presented as cut and dried. Some experts question its [[methodology]].<ref>United States of America v. Guy Randy White Horse (U.S. District Court, South Dakota Western Division 2001)</ref><ref>Smith, Gillan MacLean (1998). "Testing the Reliability and Validity of the Abel Assessment". Department of Counseling and Special Education (Brigham Young University).</ref>
Despite the test's uncertainty, [[mental health]] professionals have used the Abel Assessment to civilly commit sex offenders.
==History and testing method== Dr. Gene Abel began researching sexual interest in the early 1990s.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.drgeneabel.com/install/wp-content/uploads/2014/01/Abel-Assessment.pdf |title=The Leader in Science-based Tests for Sex Specific Evaluation & Treatment |publisher=Drgeneabel.com |accessdate=2014-02-17 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140201214455/http://www.drgeneabel.com/install/wp-content/uploads/2014/01/Abel-Assessment.pdf |archivedate=February 1, 2014 }}</ref> It was reported that he previously used the [[penile plethysmograph]] before developing the Abel Assessment.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.paulstuckle.com/InformationCenter/ChildAbuse/ThePenilePlethysmograph.aspx |title=The Penile Plethysmograph in Sexual Assault Cases |publisher=Stuckle and Associates, PLLC |date= |accessdate=2014-02-17}}</ref>
In the Abel Assessment, the subject is shown a series of slides in two separate processes. The first measures each slide's viewing time, determining the subject's reaction vis-à-vis the mean reaction. If the subject's viewing time is longer than the mean, it is said that he has a sexual interest in the image shown. For example, if the subject looks at children in bathing suits for longer than average, the Abel Assessment shows him as having an interest in children.{{citation needed|date=December 2016}}
During the second process, the individual must rate the images from 1 to 7, with 1 being revolting and 7 being sexually exciting.
==Questions of validity==
The validity of the Abel Assessment has been questioned; it has struggled at times to pass the [[Daubert standard]] for admissibility in federal and [[State court (United States)|state court]]s.<ref>{{cite web | url = http://www.atriumexperts.com/blogs/view/psychology-does-the-abel-assessment-of-sexual-interest-meet-the-daubert-criteria-for-evidence | title = PSYCHOLOGY: Does the Abel Assessment of Sexual Interest Meet the Daubert Criteria for Evidence? | accessdate = 2016-12-06}}</ref>
In 2002, the Abel Assessment was found to be inadmissible in court cases in [[Massachusetts]], a ruling that was upheld by the [[Massachusetts Court of Appeals]] in 2005.<ref name="autogenerated1">{{cite web|first=Charles Patrick |last=Ewing |url=http://www.apa.org/monitor/jan06/jn.aspx |title=Judicial Notebook – Testing tool in question |publisher=Society for the Psychological Study of Social Issues, [[American Psychological Association]]|date= January 2006 |accessdate=2014-02-17}}</ref>
The validity of the test's methodology has been criticized. Abel is said to have exaggerated various statistics in order to prove his point. In the early 90s, he announced that he had figures suggesting sex offenders commonly have multiple [[paraphilia]]s. However, Marshall and Eccles found in 1991 that he had not mentioned that he had concentrated on any offender reporting multiple deviant acts as more than one person. This greatly increased his findings.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.childmolestationprevention.org/pdfs/study.pdf |title=The Abel and Harlow Child Molestation Prevention Study |publisher=Childmolestationprevention.org |accessdate=2014-02-17}}</ref>
Abel made this assertion from the results of the report "The Abel and Harlow Child Molestation Prevention Study". The report was never subject to [[peer review]] or published in any [[professional journal]]. There is also no in-depth detail about his methodology available. The Abel Assessment is based on these findings.<ref>{{cite web|last=Frances |first=Allen |url=http://www.psychiatrictimes.com/articles/warning-sign-road-dsm-v-beware-its-unintended-consequences |title=A Warning Sign on the Road to DSM-V: Beware of Its Unintended Consequences |publisher=Psychiatric Times |date=2009-06-26 |accessdate=2014-02-17}} (membership required for access).</ref>
In a 2002 decision on the admissibility of the test by Texas appellate judge Brian Quinn, the court said that since Abel's proprietary scoring methodology is not publicly known, it "could be mathematically based, founded upon indisputable empirical research, or simply the magic of young Harry Potter's mixing potions at the Hogwarts School of Witchcraft and Wizardry".<ref name=Chammah/>
Abel states in his book that a therapist can use the test as a tool to determine if a child is attracted to other children. The 9th Circuit Court of Appeals also ruled in 2004 that the Abel Assessment is a tool that is used only as [[Therapy|treatment]], and that it cannot detect whether a person has sexually abused children. Independent studies of the Abel Assessment have concluded it to be unreliable in adults and that there is not yet enough information to support its use with adolescents.
The Diana Screen is another test developed by Abel and his associates.<ref>{{cite news | last =Micolucci | first =Vic | coauthors = | title =Test could be missing link in background checks | newspaper =[[WJXT|NBC 4 Jax]] | location = | pages = | language = | publisher = | date =27 June 2013 | url = http://www.news4jax.com/news/does-new-test-prevent-child-sex-abuse/-/475880/20745492/-/i7cgnuz/-/index.html | accessdate =24 November 2013 }}</ref> It, too, has been a source of controversy for Abel due to it being a pass/fail test.{{citation needed|date=November 2017}}
==References== {{Reflist}}
==External links== * [http://abelscreening.com/ Abel Screening, Inc.] official web site
[[Category:Sex and the law]]

revision.text:
{{Infobox organization |name= The American–Israeli Cooperative Enterprise |logo=American Israeli Cooperative Enterprise logo.jpg |logo_size=200px |type= |founded_date=1993{{cite book|author1=Arnold Dashefsky|author2=Ira M. Sheskin|title=American Jewish Year Book 2015: The Annual Record of the North American Jewish Communities|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=gaqFCwAAQBAJ&pg=PA525|date=3 February 2016|publisher=Springer|isbn=978-3-319-24505-8|pages=525–}} |founder=[[Mitchell Bard]] |location=[[Chevy Chase (Washington, D.C.)]], Maryland |origins= |key_people=Howard Rosenbloom (President)
Mitchell G. Bard (Executive Director)
Dr. Arthur Bard (Vice President)
Dr. Daniel Lieber (Secretary)
Norman Goldstein (Treasurer){{cite web | title=Board of Directors | website=Jewish Virtual Library | url=http://www.jewishvirtuallibrary.org/board-of-directors | access-date=December 31, 2017}} |area_served= |focus= |method= |revenue= |endowment= |num_employees= |owner= |Non-profit_slogan= |homepage= }} '''The American–Israeli Cooperative Enterprise''' ('''AICE''') is a non-profit [[501(c)(3)]] U.S.-based organization established in 1993 "to strengthen the [[Israel–United States relations|U.S.-Israel relationship]]."{{cite web | title=American-Israeli Cooperative Enterprise | website=Crunchbase | url=https://www.crunchbase.com/organization/american-israeli-cooperative-enterprise | access-date=December 31, 2017}} ==Organization structure== AICE's goals are enhancing the understanding and appreciation of Israel through social and educational programs in the United States, disseminating information about Israel; aiding efforts of students and faculty attempting to counteract [[anti-Zionist]] rhetoric and activities; promoting the study of Israel’s political system, culture, and society; and developing American universities’ appreciation of Israel as a subject worthy of serious attention. AICE's goals also include highlighting areas where Israel might contribute to the betterment of America, and publishing studies to identify specific programs and approaches that can benefit [[Americans]]. According to its mission statement, AICE aims to provide a vehicle for research, study and discussion between the peoples and governments of the United States and Israel; to facilitate of partnership between both nations; organize and publish joint activities that benefit the two; and provide resources, material, and more to promote scholarship in the field of Israel studies.{{cite web|title=About AICE|url=http://www.jewishvirtuallibrary.org/about-aice|work=JVL|accessdate=27 October 2013}} Over the years, AICE's material has been cited by news and media outlets such as [[CNN]],{{cite news|title=Rabbi, wife 'spread Jewish pride' in Mumbai|url=http://edition.cnn.com/2008/WORLD/asiapcf/11/28/india.jewish.center.attack/index.html?iref=mpstoryview|accessdate=21 December 2013|newspaper=CNN - Asia}} [[Yahoo news]],{{cite news|last=Vasilogambros|first=Matt|title=Could John Kerry Broker a Mideast Peace Deal? Probably Not|url=https://news.yahoo.com/could-john-kerry-broker-mideast-peace-deal-probably-153615506--politics.html|newspaper=Yahoo|accessdate=21 December 2013|date=January 28, 2013}} [[Haaretz]],{{cite news|last=Neistat|first=Aimee|title=Israeli photo exhibition opens a window into the lives of Georgian Jews|url=http://www.haaretz.com/jewish-world/israeli-photo-exhibition-opens-a-window-into-the-lives-of-georgian-jews-1.420044|accessdate=21 December 2013|newspaper=Haaretz|date=March 22, 2012}} [[USA Today]]{{cite web | title=Jerusalem timeline: a city rich with history, steeped in change | website=USA TODAY | date=June 8, 2015 | url=https://www.usatoday.com/story/news/2015/06/08/jerusalem-timeline-history-supreme-court/28711565/ | access-date=December 31, 2017}} and others. A member of the [[Israel on Campus Coalition]],{{cite web|title=Tenured or Tenduous: Defining the Role of Faculty in Supporting Israel on Campus|url=https://www.jewishvirtuallibrary.org/pub/Tenured_or_Tenuous.pdf|work=JVL|accessdate=5 February 2014}} AICE is independently supported by donations from various foundations and individuals.{{cite web|last=Koren|first=Annette|title=Advancing Israel Studies in U.S. Universities 2005-2008: The American-Israeli Cooperative Enterprise|url=http://www.bjpa.org/Publications/downloadFile.cfm?FileID=17816|work=[[Brandeis University]]|publisher=[[Berman Jewish Policy Archive @ NYU Wagner]]|date=September 2008|accessdate=20 March 2014}} [[Shlomo Avineri]], [[Gerald Steinberg]], Joshua Teitelbaum,{{cite web|title=AICE Conference Participant Bios 2013-2014 |url=http://bomah.org/media/ConferenceBios2013-2014.pdf |accessdate=27 October 2013 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131029200438/http://bomah.org/media/ConferenceBios2013-2014.pdf |archivedate=29 October 2013 }} [[Bernice Manocherian]]{{cite web|title=AICE - board of directors|url=https://www.jewishvirtuallibrary.org/jsource/board.html|accessdate=10 May 2014}} are among the organization's board members. ==Activities== AICE maintains a database that containing joint U.S.-Israel activities. The database includes recipients of grants from the [[Binational Science Foundation]] (BSF), the Binational Agricultural Research and Development Foundation (BARD) and the Binational Industrial Research and Development Foundation (BIRD). Its Economic Partnership Databank contains information on more than 10,000 U.S. companies doing business in or with Israel. To address the critical need to develop new scholars and place established Israel scholars on campus, AICE has created the Israel Scholar Development Fund (ISDF). Some of their other major projects include bringing Israeli professors to teach Israel-related courses on U.S campuses, supporting visiting Israeli scholars teaching in the US. ===Visiting Israeli Professors (VIPs)=== AICE fellowship program, "Schusterman Visiting Israeli Professors",{{cite web|title=Israel |url=http://www.schusterman.org/interests/israel/schusterman-visiting-israel-professors |archive-url=https://archive.is/20140510224508/http://www.schusterman.org/interests/israel/schusterman-visiting-israel-professors |dead-url=yes |archive-date=10 May 2014 |work=Charles & Lynn Schusterman Family Foundation |accessdate=10 May 2014 }} brings Israeli academics to American campuses{{cite web | title=The year BDS became the number one concern for American Jews | website=haaretz.com | date=December 27, 2014 | url=https://www.haaretz.com/jewish/features/.premium-1.633972 | access-date=December 31, 2017}} in order to ensure that expertise in the field will continue to be available from Israel while expanding within the United States. Visiting Israeli professors come from the Israeli universities [[Hebrew University]], [[University of Haifa]], [[Tel Aviv University]], [[Ben Gurion University]], and [[Bar Ilan University]]. In 2008, AICE financially assisted 29 Israelis (26 professors and three postdoctoral fellows) offering 70 courses in 27 universities throughout the United States and a further 11 graduate fellows and two postdoctoral research fellows. In the 2014-15 academic year, AICE reportedly selected 20 VIPs.https://israbib.wordpress.com/2012/07/10/fvipus1314/ ===Other Projects=== AICE's initiatives also include: *[http://www.iranintelligence.com/ Intelligence on Iran]: A free, online resource providing in-depth expert analysis, extensive primary source material, and a news media archive covering aspects and issues related to the [[Nuclear program of Iran|Iranian nuclear program]]".{{cite web|title=iranintelligence - About|url=http://www.iranintelligence.com/aboutus|accessdate=5 February 2014}} *The Dream Team Initiative and Campus Intelligence Project: An initiative created with the purpose of countering the boycott Israel movement and other attacks against Israel, and investigating the subject. *[http://www.stopbds.com/ "Stop BDS project]: Launched in 2010, it is an online resource for students on campus and others who wish to fight the anti-Israel [[Boycott, Divestment and Sanctions]] (BDS) movement in their communities.{{cite web|title=STOPBDS.COM and BDS Cookbook Developed to Fight Boycotts on Campuses |url=http://www.jnf.org/caravan-for-democracy/news/bdscookbook.html |work=[[Jewish National Fund]] |accessdate=5 February 2014 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140222034225/http://www.jnf.org/caravan-for-democracy/news/bdscookbook.html |archivedate=22 February 2014 }} *[http://joesisrael.com/about/ Joe’s Israel]: A social media campaign launched on the web, which provides a platform to empower college students in North America for a dialogue on Israel.{{cite web|last=[[Andre Oboler]]|title=Joe’s Israel: Empowerment through Social Media|url=http://blogs.jpost.com/content/joe%E2%80%99s-israel-empowerment-through-social-media|publisher=[[Jpost]]|date=September 3, 2012|accessdate=5 February 2014}} *[http://www.israelcalendar.org/ "The Israel Calendar"]: A web-based calendar, was designed to provide the pro-Israel community a monthly focus to structure Israel activism on college campuses and in Jewish communities.{{cite web|title=The Israel Calendar - About|url=http://www.israelcalendar.org/index.php?indpge=8&ve=-1&postId=4|accessdate=5 February 2014}} ===Publications=== Books published by the American–Israeli Cooperative Enterprise include:{{cite web|title=AICE - Publications|url=https://www.jewishvirtuallibrary.org/aice-publications|accessdate=5 February 2014}} *{{cite book|author=Mitchell Geoffrey Bard|title=Myths And Facts: A Guide to the Arab-Israeli Conflict|url=https://smile.amazon.com/Myths-Facts-Guide-Arab-Israeli-Conflict-ebook/dp/B01MR12ZXU/ref=sr_1_1?ie=UTF8&qid=1524061157&sr=8-1&keywords=myths+and+facts|year=2017|publisher=American-Israeli Cooperative Enterprise|isbn=1537152726}} *{{cite book|author1=Mitchell Geoffrey Bard|author2=Jeff Dawson|author3=American-Israeli Cooperative Enterprise|title=Israel and the Campus: The Real Story|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=iQJHkgEACAAJ|year=2012|publisher=American-Israeli Cooperative Enterprise}}* *{{cite book|author1=Mitchell Geoffrey Bard|author2=Israel on Campus Coalition|author3=American-Israeli Cooperative Enterprise|title=Tenured Or Tenuous: Defining the Role of Faculty in Supporting Israel on Campus|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=NJIbMwEACAAJ|year=2004|publisher=Israel on Campus Coalition}} *{{cite book|author=Irvin M. Asher|title=Breakthrough Dividend: Israeli Innovations in Biotechnology that Could Benefit Americans|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=4i66GwAACAAJ|year=1995|publisher=American-Israeli Cooperative Enterprise}} ==External links== *[http://www.jewishvirtuallibrary.org/ Official Website] ==References== {{Reflist|30em}} {{Organized Jewish Life in the United States|state=collapsed}} {{DEFAULTSORT:American-Israeli Cooperative Enterprise}} [[Category:Jewish organizations based in the United States]] [[Category:Jewish studies research institutes]] [[Category:Jewish educational organizations]] [[Category:Charities based in Washington, D.C.]] [[Category:1993 establishments in the United States]] [[Category:Israel–United States relations]] [[Category:Jewish organizations]] [[Category:Research institutes in the United States]]

revision.comment: Rescued 1 archive link; reformat 1 link. [[User:GreenC/WaybackMedic_2.1|Wayback Medic 2.1]]
revision.text:
[[Image:Aphrodite Kallipygos-Hermitage-(crop).jpg|thumb|Copy of a [[Hellenistic period|Hellenistic]] [[Aphrodite Kallipygos]] at [[Hermitage Museum|The Hermitage]] in [[St. Petersburg]].]] '''Anasyrma''' ({{lang-grc|ἀνάσυρμα}}) composed of ἀνά ''ana'' "up, against, back", and σύρμα ''syrma'' "skirt"; plural: '''anasyrmata''' ({{lang|grc|ἀνασύρματα}}), also called '''anasyrmos''' ({{lang|grc|ἀνασυρμός}}),<ref>{{cite book |last=Blackledge |first=Catherine |year=2009 |title=The Story of V: A Natural History of Female Sexuality |location=New Brunswick, New Jersey |publisher=Rutgers University Press |page=12 |isbn=978-0813534558}}<!-- year was given as 2003, might be error, might be earlier edition--></ref> is the [[gesture]] of lifting the [[skirt]] or [[kilt]]. It is used in connection with certain [[religion|religious]] [[ritual]]s, eroticism, and lewd jokes (see, for example, [[Baubo]]). The term is used in describing corresponding works of [[art]]. Anasyrma differs from "flashing", a physically similar gesture as an act of [[exhibitionism]], in that an exhibitionist has an implied purpose of his/her own sexual arousal, while anasyrma is done only for the effect on the onlookers.{{citation needed|date=July 2018}}
Anasyrma is effectively "the exposing of the genitals". This is a form of exhibitionism found in religion or artwork, rather than a display for arousal, and it always refers to the act of a woman exposing herself. The act of lifting up one's skirt to display the genitals can be an [[:en:wiktionary:apotropaic|apotropaic]] device; it can, in circumstances of war, evoke the fear of the enemy. It can also be an act that evokes surprise and subsequent laughter and a letting go of sadness. What is significant about anasyrma is that it reflects the numinous quality of the female genitals and the genital region through which birth ensues. In several cultures, there is a myth of anasyrma used for emotional healing.<ref>{{cite book |author=Miriam Robbins Dexter |author2=Victor H. Mair |title=Sacred Display: Divine and Magical Female Figures of Eurasia |publisher=Cambria Press |year=2010 |isbn=978-1604976748}}{{page needed|date=October 2016}}</ref>
Anasyrma may be a deliberately provocative self-exposing of one's naked [[genitals]] or [[buttocks]]. The famous example of the latter case is [[Aphrodite Kallipygos]] ("Aphrodite of the beautiful buttocks"). In many traditions, this gesture also has an [[apotrope|apotropaic]] character, as a mockery or means to ward off a supernatural enemy, analogous to [[mooning]].
==Greek antiquity== [[Image:Ermafrodito pubblicato in Marjon van der Meulen, Rubens Copies after the Antique.jpg|thumb|upright|left|[[Hermaphroditus|Ermafrodito]] ''anasyromenos'' sketch by [[Peter Paul Rubens]].]] Ritual jesting and intimate exposure were common in the cults of [[Demeter]] and [[Dionysus]], and figure in the celebration of the [[Eleusinian mysteries]] associated with these divinities. The mythographer [[Apollodorus of Athens|Apollodorus]] says that Iambe's jesting was the reason for the practice of ritual jesting at the [[Thesmophoria]], a festival celebrated in honor of Demeter and Persephone. In other versions of the myth of Demeter, the goddess is received by a woman named Baubo, a [[crone]] who makes her laugh by exposing herself, in a ritual gesture called anasyrma ("lifting [of skirts]"). A set of statuettes from [[Priene]], a Greek city on the west coast of Asia Minor, are usually identified as "[[Baubo]]" figurines, representing the female body as the face conflated with the lower part of the abdomen. These appeared as counterparts to the [[phallus]]es decorated with eyes, mouth, and sometimes legs, that appeared on vase paintings and were made as statuettes.
Terracotta [[hermaphrodite]] figurines in the so-called ''anasyromenos'' pose, with female breasts and a long garment lifted to reveal male genitals have been found from [[Sicily]] to [[Lesbos]], dating back to the late [[Classical Greece|Classical]] and early [[Hellenistic period]]. The ''anasyromenos'' pose, however, was not invented in the 4th century BCE, figures of this type drew on a much earlier [[Eastern world|eastern]] [[Iconography|iconographic]] tradition employed for female divinities.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ik-morphomata.uni-koeln.de/fileadmin/user_upload/Fluide%20Ko%CC%88rper/Ajootian_abstract%26CV.pdf |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20131216191227/http://www.ik-morphomata.uni-koeln.de/fileadmin/user_upload/Fluide%20Ko%CC%88rper/Ajootian_abstract%26CV.pdf |dead-url=yes |archive-date=2013-12-16 |author=Aileen Ajootian |title=Hermaphroditos ανασυρόμενος: Revealing the Body |publisher=University of Mississippi |format=PDF |date= |accessdate=2012-08-01 }}</ref> Ancient literature suggests that the figures represent the androgynous Cypriot deity [[Aphroditus]] (possibly a form of [[Astarte]]),<ref>{{cite web|url=http://jewishencyclopedia.com/articles/2005-ashtoreth#anchor4|title=Ashtoreth: In Arabia|publisher=[[Jewish Encyclopedia]]|accessdate=2013-06-26}}</ref> whose cult was introduced into mainland Greece between the 5th–4th century BCE. The revealed [[phallus]] was believed to have [[apotropaic magic]]al powers, averting the [[evil eye]] or ''[[invidia]]'' and bestowing [[good luck]].
==Apotropaic effect of nakedness== Many historical references suggest that anasyrma had dramatic or supernatural effect—positive or negative. [[Pliny the Elder]] wrote that a [[menstruating]] woman who uncovers her body can scare away [[hailstorms]], whirlwinds and lightning. If she strips naked and walks around the field, caterpillars, worms and beetles fall off the ears of corn. Even when not menstruating, she can lull a storm out at sea by stripping.<ref>{{cite book|author=Pliny the Younger|title=Natural History|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=R5QVAAAAYAAJ&pg=PA262&lpg=PA262&dq=hailstorms+whirlwinds+and+lightnings+will+even+be+scared+away+by+a+woman+uncovering+her+body#v=onepage&q&f=false|chapter=xxviii. c.23}}</ref> [[File:La Fontaine - Tales and Novels in verse - v2 p130.jpg|thumb|upright|La Fontaine plate]]
According to folklore, women lifted their skirts to chase off enemies in [[Ireland]] and [[China]].<ref>{{cite web |title=10 Questions: Miriam Robbins Dexter on the Power of Female Display |publisher=UCLA Program on Central Asia |date=October 6, 2010 |url=http://www.international.ucla.edu/asia/centralasia/article/117670 |accessdate=2012-08-01}}</ref> A story from ''[[The Irish Times]]'' (September 23, 1977) reported a potentially violent incident involving several men, which was averted by a woman exposing her genitals to the attackers. According to [[Balkans|Balkan]] folklore, when it rained too much, women would run into the fields and lift their skirts to scare the gods and end the rain. <ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.artnet.com/galleries/sean-kelly-gallery/marina-abramovic-balkan-erotic-epic/ |title=Marina Abramovic: Balkan Erotic Epic |publisher=Sean Kelly Gallery |location=New York |date=December 9, 2005}}</ref> In [[Jean de La Fontaine]]'s ''Nouveaux Contes'' (1674), a demon is repulsed by the sight of a woman lifting her skirt. Associated carvings, called [[sheela na gig]]s, were common on medieval churches in northern Europe and the British Isles.
In some nations of [[Africa]], a woman stripping naked and displaying herself is still considered a curse and a means to ward off evil.<ref>{{cite news |author= Alexis Okeowo | title = The Ivory Coast Effect | url = http://www.newyorker.com/news/news-desk/the-ivory-coast-effect | date = March 21, 2011 | work = The New Yorker | accessdate = 2011-03-22}}</ref> As women give life, they can take it away. In [[Nigeria]], among other places, women invoked the curse only under the most extreme circumstances, and men who are exposed are considered dead. No one will cook for them, marry them, enter into any kind of contract with them or buy anything from them. The curse extends to foreign men as well, who will go impotent or suffer some great harm.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.imow.org/wpp/stories/viewStory?storyId=1098 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080525164953/http://www.imow.org/wpp/stories/viewStory?storyId=1098 |dead-url=yes |archive-date=2008-05-25 |title=The Curse of Nakedness |publisher=Imow.org |date= |accessdate=2012-08-01 }}</ref>
In Nigeria, during mass protests against the [[petroleum industry]], women displayed themselves in [[anasyrma]].<ref>{{cite news |author=Geraldine Sealey |url=http://abcnews.go.com/International/story?id=79895 |title=Naked Ploy Is Latest Threat in Oil Wars |publisher=ABC News |date=2002-07-31 |accessdate=2012-08-01}}</ref> [[Leymah Gbowee]] used anasyrma when trying to bring peace during the [[Second Liberian Civil War]].<ref>{{cite magazine |author=Kevin Conley |url=http://www.oprah.com/omagazine/Leymah-Gbowee-and-Abigail-Disney-Shoot-for-Peace-in-Liberia/5 |title=The Rabble Rousers |magazine=O, The Oprah Magazine |date=December 2008 |accessdate=2012-08-01}}</ref>
==See also== * [[Nudity and protest]] * [[Exhibitionism]] (Martymachlia) * [[Indecent exposure]] * [[Mooning]] * [[Upskirt]] * [[Can-can]]

{{Primarysources|date=April 2016}}{{Infobox Organization |name = Bioversity International |image = Bioversity_logo.svg |size = 210px |motto = Agricultural biodiversity nourishes and sustains the planet |formation = 1974 |type = Non-profit research-for-development |status = [[International organisation]] |purpose = Research for development |headquarters = Maccarese, [[Rome]] |location = [[Italy]] {{Flagicon|Italy}} |region_served = 18 offices worldwide |leader_title = Director General |leader_name = <ref>[http://www.bioversityinternational.org/about-us/who-we-are/staff-bios/single-details-bios/tutwiler-m-ann/ M. Ann Tutwiler]</ref> M. Ann Tutwiler |num_staff = Approx. 300 |website = {{URL|www.bioversityinternational.org}} }}
'''Bioversity International''' is a global research-for-development organization with a vision – that [[agricultural biodiversity]] nourishes people and sustains the planet. The organization delivers scientific evidence, management practices and policy options to use and safeguard [[agricultural biodiversity]] to attain global [[food security|food]] and nutrition security, working with partners in low-income countries in different regions where agricultural biodiversity can contribute to improved nutrition, resilience, productivity and [[climate change adaptation]].
Bioversity International is a member of the [[CGIAR]], a global research partnership for a food-secure future.
The organization is highly decentralized, with about 300 staff working around the world.<ref>[http://www.bioversityinternational.org/about-us/where-we-work/ Where Bioversity International works]</ref> Its headquarters are in [[Maccarese]], outside Rome, Italy, with regional offices located in Central and South America, West and Central Africa, East and Southern Africa, Central and South Asia, and South-east Asia.
== Background == Bioversity International is a research-for-development organization focused on safeguarding and using [[agricultural biodiversity]] to help meet challenges such as adaptation to [[climate change]] and increased [[sustainable production]].<ref>[http://www.bioversityinternational.org/e-library/publications/detail/bioversity-internationals-10-year-strategy-2014-2024 Bioversity International 10-year Strategy 2014-2024]</ref>
The organization takes the view that the diversity of plants and animals offers opportunities not only through [[Sexual reproduction|breeding]] but also by delivering many other benefits. Some are direct, such as the better nutrition and greater sustainability that come with locally-adapted crops. Others are indirect, like the [[ecosystem services]] delivered by healthy populations of [[pollinator]]s, [[biological control]] agents, and [[soil microbes]]. Agricultural biodiversity will also be absolutely essential to cope with the predicted impacts of climate change, not simply as a source of traits but as the underpinnings of more resilient farm ecosystems.<ref>[http://www.bioversityinternational.org/e-library/publications/detail/agricultural-biodiversity-is-essential-for-a-sustainable-improvement-in-food-and-nutrition-security Frison, E.A.; Cherfas, J.; Hodgkin, T. Agricultural Biodiversity Is Essential for a Sustainable Improvement in Food and Nutrition Security. Sustainability 2011, 3, 238-253.]</ref>
== Governance == Bioversity International is governed by a Board of Trustees, including one Trustee nominated by the host country (Italy) and one nominated by [[FAO]]. The Board also appoints the Director General who manages the operation of the various programs. The current Director General, M. Ann Tutwiler<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.cgiar.org/about-us/our-governance/center-director-generals/profile/tutwiler/|title=CGIAR Center Director Generals - Bioversity International|last=|first=|date=|website=www.cgiar.org|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=26 January 2018}}</ref>, will remain in her position until the end of 2018.
==History== In 2014, Bioversity International marked 40 years of operations. Bioversity International was originally established by the CGIAR as the International Board for [[Plant Genetic Resources]] (IBPGR) in 1974. In October 1991, IBPGR became the International Plant Genetic Resources Institute (IPGRI) and in 1994 IPGRI began independent operation as one of the centers of the CGIAR. At the request of the CGIAR, in 1994 IPGRI took over the governance and administration of the International Network for the Improvement of Banana and Plantain (INIBAP). In 2006, IPGRI and INIBAP became a single organization and subsequently changed their operating name to Bioversity International. Bioversity International still maintains the world's largest banana [[genetic database|gene bank]], the Bioversity International ''Musa'' Germplasm Transit Centre, that is hosted at the [[KU Leuven|Katholieke Universiteit Leuven]] (KU Leuven) in Leuven, Belgium, and manages [[ProMusa]] - a platform that shares knowledge about [[Banana|bananas]] and [[Cooking banana|plantains]].<ref>[http://www.bioversityinternational.org/about-us/who-we-are/history/ Bioversity International history]</ref> In 2002, the [[Crop Trust|Global Crop Diversity Trust]] was established by Bioversity International on behalf of the CGIAR and the [[Food and Agriculture Organization|UN Food and Agriculture Organization]], through a Crop Diversity Endowment Fund<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://time.com/doomsday-vault/|title=Inside the 'Doomsday' Vault|last=|first=|date=|work=TIME|access-date=26 January 2018|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=}}</ref>.
==Publications== Bioversity International and its predecessors have published occasional papers under the title ''Issues in Genetic Resources''. In 2017, the organization published ''Mainstreaming Agrobiodiversity In Sustainable Food Systems - Scientific Foundations for an Agrobiodiversity Index'', a book that put the spotlight on the importance of [[Agricultural biodiversity|agrobiodiversity]] as the foundation of our food supplies<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/environment/2017/sep/26/sixth-mass-extinction-of-wildlife-also-threatens-global-food-supplies|title=Sixth mass extinction of wildlife also threatens global food supplies|last=|first=|date=|website=The Guardian|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref>.

[[File:Beethoven pf son 32 title.jpg|thumb|Original title page for the Piano Sonata, Opus 111]] The '''Catalogues of Beethoven compositions''' are all of the different ways in which the [[List of compositions by Ludwig van Beethoven|musical compositions]] by [[Ludwig van Beethoven]] have been organized by researchers into his music. ==The problem== When Beethoven died, he left (as many other composers) a great many compositions behind. In Beethoven's case, a sizable majority of his works were published. However, some works were not published, and some works were unfinished, either because he had laid them aside, or died before he could finish them. The catalogues described here are attempts to organize and identify with precision all of these works in ways that are useful to musicologists, musicians, and the listening public. Most of Beethoven's best known works were published in his lifetime, and bear opus numbers, with which they may be reliably identified. The short piano piece "[[Für Elise]]" is a notable exception: it is usually designated [[WoO]] (Werke ohne Opuszahl – literally, "works without opus number") 59. ==Opus number== [[File:Beethoven_bust_statue_by_Hagen.jpg|thumb|right|100px|A bust of Beethoven, based on his 1812 life mask]] The traditional 19th-century method of identifying a composer's works was for publishers to assign some sort of consecutive [[Opus number]] to the works as they were published. This method is not entirely satisfactory to anyone. Musicians and the listening public have no reliable way to distinguish different works with similar characteristics. Musicologists cannot reliably identify unpublished works, nor do they have a reliable indication from the opus number of the actual composition date(s). For example, the [[Octet (Beethoven)|Octet]], written from 1792 to 1793 is Opus 103, while Opus 102 and Opus 104 were written in 1815 and 1817 respectively. Some opus numbers comprise multiple pieces; 172 works are divided among 138 opus numbers. All of Beethoven's compositions up to and including Opus 135 were published in Beethoven's lifetime; later numbers were published posthumously, and are generally denoted by "Op. posth." ==Kinsky catalogue== {{see also|WoO (Beethoven)|List of compositions by Ludwig van Beethoven#List of works by number}} In 1955, [[Georg Kinsky]] and [[Hans Halm]] published a catalogue of Beethoven's works, in which they assigned numbers to 205 "Werke ohne Opuszahl" (meaning "works without opus number" in German) to ''some'' of Beethoven's unpublished works. These numbers given these works are generally preceded by "[[WoO]]". The Kinsky–Halm catalogue also lists 18 works in an appendix as being either doubtfully attributed, or simply spurious. Some of those listed as doubtful have since been shown to be authored by Beethoven.{{Example needed}} These numbers are generally preceded by "Anh.", short for German ''Anhang'', meaning ''appendix''. ==Hess catalogue== The Swiss composer and musicologist [[Willy Hess (composer)|Willy Hess]] also researched and published a catalogue in the 1950s, in which he included pieces not included in the 19th century [[Beethoven Gesamtausgabe|complete edition]] published by [[Breitkopf and Härtel]]. Hess included many more fragmentary works than did Kinsky, and his catalog runs to 335 entries in the "Hauptkatalog" (main catalogue), and 66 "doubtful and falsely-attributed" works in an appendix. Many pieces have both WoO and H numbers.{{Example needed}} ==Biamonti catalogue== Beethoven's compositions are also organized through the [[Biamonti Catalogue]], compiled by [[Giovanni Biamonti]] and published in 1968. This work is an attempt to chronologically order all of Beethoven's creative output, in a manner similar to the catalogue of [[Franz Schubert]]'s works by [[Otto Erich Deutsch]]. It combines the pieces with opus numbers, all of the works from the Kinsky and Hess catalogues, and previously uncatalogued fragments, into a single list comprising 849 entries. ==Catalogues== The following references identify the major catalogues of Beethoven's works. *[[Gustav Nottebohm|Nottebohm, Gustav]]. ''Thematisches Verzeichnis der im Druck erschienenen Werke von Ludwig van Beethoven''. Leipzig, Breitkopf & Härtel, 1925. {{OCLC|4763103}}. Reprinted Wiesbaden: M. Sändig, 1969 {{OCLC|1828776}}.
—Historically important thematic catalogue, by a pioneering 19th Century Beethoven scholar.
—Full title in English: ''Thematic Catalogue of the Published Works of Ludwig van Beethoven''. *Kinsky, G. and H. Halm. ''Das Werk Beethovens: thematisch-bibliographisches Verzeichnis seiner sämtlichen vollendeten Kompositionen''. München: G. Henle, 1955. {{OCLC|334667}}
—The standard thematic and bibliographical catalogue of Beethoven's works.
—Full title in English: ''Beethoven's Works: thematic and bibliographic catalogue of all his completed compositions by Georg Kinsky, completed and edited after the author's death by Hans Halm''. *[[Willy Hess (composer)|Hess, Willy]]. ''Verzeichnis der nicht in der Gesamtausgabe veröffentlichen Werke Ludwig van Beethovens''. Wiesbaden: Breitkopf & Härtel, 1957. {{OCLC|18406510}}
—Hess' original study and catalogue; still more widely available in libraries than Green's edition.
—Full title in English: ''Catalogue of works not found in the Collected Works of Ludwig van Beethoven''. *Green, James (ed. and trans). ''The new Hess catalog of Beethoven’s works''. West Newbury, Vermont: Vance Brook, 2003. {{ISBN|0-9640570-3-4}} (also it. transl. James F. Green, ''Il nuovo catalogo Hess delle opere di Beethoven'', translated by Cristoforo Prodan, Zecchini Editore, Varese, 2006)
—An English translation of [[Willy Hess (composer)|Willy Hess]]'s important 1957 catalogue and study, updated to reflect more recent scholarship. *Biamonti, Giovanni. ''Catologo cronologico e tematico delle opere di Beethoven''. Torino: ILTE, 1968. {{OCLC|2028666}}
—Encompasses works with and without opus numbers, as well as sketches and fragments, in 849 chronologically arranged entries.
—Full title in English: ''Chronological and Thematic Catalogue of the works of Beethoven''. ==Sources== {{Refbegin}} * Johnson, Douglas and Scott G. Burnham. "Beethoven, Ludwig Van (Works)", [http://www.grovemusic.com Grove Music Online] ed. L. Macy (Subscription access). Accessed 2007-04-19.
—Includes categorized works list with bibliographical and other information. * [[Maynard Solomon|Solomon, Maynard]]. ''Beethoven'' (1st edition). New York: Schirmer, 1977. {{ISBN|0-02-872460-7}}. pp. 372, 386–391.
—Popular biographical study; includes bibliographical notes and (incomplete) works lists. {{Refend}} {{Ludwig van Beethoven}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Catalogues Of Beethoven Compositions}} [[Category:Ludwig van Beethoven]] [[Category:Music catalogues|Beethoven]]

{{multiple issues| {{Orphan|date=February 2014}} {{external links|date=February 2014}} }} The concept of '''healthcare knowledge transfer using [[cinematography]]''' recognizes that films with carefully crafted and verified content, using graphics, animations and live-action video, can be one of the most efficient ways of transferring knowledge with clarity and speed, to both lay-people and healthcare professionals.
==History of medical cinematography==
===Late 19th century===
The use of cinematography to enhance healthcare practice and delivery dates back to the late 19th century in Western Europe. [[Étienne-Jules Marey]] (French scientist and physiologist), [[Eugène-Louis Doyen]] (French surgeon), [[Bolesław Matuszewski]] (Polish cameraman, in France his first name was written as Boleslas), and [[Gheorghe Marinescu]] (Romanian neurologist) are some of the pioneers of medical cinematography.<ref>Geneviève Aubert. Arthur Van Gehuchten takes neurology to the movies. NEUROLOGY 2002;59:1612–1618</ref>
In 1888, Doyen had his surgeries captured on film. His films were brought into disrepute by the fact that they were copied and shown on fairgrounds. The resulting social prejudice may explain the slow take-off of medical cinematography. For example, in 1910 someone said the following regarding Doyen’s videos: ,“These pictures savoured of advertisement, and were never popular, save as a side show among the less scientifically inclined members of the profession.” <ref>Roentgen Cinematography. The British Medical Journal, Vol. 2, No. 2603 (Nov. 19, 1910), p. 1645</ref> Doyen’s work, however, marked the distinction between the concepts of ‘film for entertainment’ versus ‘film for medicine’.
In 1893 Marey used the technique to study human physiology and [https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=11lKItGNuiY movement]. In 1898 Boleslas Matuszewski recorded medical films in Paris (at the time, the world’s neurologic capital). At [[Pitié-Salpêtrière Hospital|Salpêtrière and Pitié hospitals]] he filmed surgeries and cases of persons affected by nervous and mental disorders.
Gheorghe Marinescu (Romanian neurologist) studied under renowned French professor [[Jean-Martin Charcot]] and returned to Bucharest as Chief Physician at Pantelimon Hospital. Between 1898–1902 he conducted a cinematographic project, recording and analyzing a series of neurological conditions in patients. He perfected the application of filming techniques to clinical [[neurology]] and published five articles based on cinematographic analysis. Marinescu wrote that the role of cinematography is “to complement and even replace, in whatever measure possible, the descriptive exposition of phenomena by more rigorous, more exact analysis, which consists of recording movement with the help of special procedures” <ref>Barboi A C, Goetz C, Musetoiu R. The origins of scientific cinematography and early medical applications. NEUROLOGY 2004;62:2082–2086</ref>
In 1905 [[Arthur Van Gehuchten]] (Belgian anatomist and neurologist) began to film neurologic patients and built up a collection of films for teaching purposes. His collection is exceptional both quantitatively and qualitatively.<ref>Geneviève Aubert. Idem.</ref>
===Early 20th century: medical cinematography as [[propaganda]]===
In 1910 [[Thomas Edison]] produced the first ever public [[health education]] film, raising awareness about the prevention of [[tuberculosis]]. The view at the time was that “propagandists saw education as limited to providing facts. Propaganda was designed to control opinions and actions, without having to use direct force. Propaganda appealed to most progressive health reformers as a way of providing genuine popular democratic support for the trained medical elite.
Dr. H. E. Kleinschmidt of the Tuberculosis Association defined good propaganda as ‘mental inoculation’ whose avowed goal was ‘will-control through education’. The goal of health propagandists was not simply to inform but to persuade, to control individual thoughts and actions.” <ref name="Martin">Martin S. Pernick. Thomas Edison's Tuberculosis Films: Mass Media and Health Propaganda. The Hastings Center Report, Vol. 8, No. 3 (Jun., 1978), pp. 21-27</ref>
Edison’s film came under criticism for “the distortions, exaggerations, and inaccuracies inherent in the [[melodrama]] format. The films clearly exaggerated the power of medicine to deal with tuberculosis; and they greatly over dramatized the effects and symptoms of the disease.” <ref name="Martin" />
During World War I, the use of medical propaganda appealed to the US government and private agencies, which worked together “to produce and distribute anti-[[venereal disease]] motion pictures, including the feature-length melodramas [https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0010131/ Fit to Fight] and The End of the Road and other lesser-known films. These movies, originally made for military trainees and war workers, were revised for showing to civilians, as evidence mounted that many soldiers had been infected prior to induction.” <ref>Martin S. Pernick. Sex Education Films. Isis, Vol. 84, No. 4 (Dec., 1993), pp. 766-768</ref>
===Medical cinematography employed in healthcare===
The 1930s saw the rise of medical cinematography employed to reach goals of [[public health]]. In 1933, the Journal of Communication published an article regarding [[immunization]] propaganda in the US: “Dr. Nash has enlisted the cinematograph film. He has noticed that American films illustrating immunization never show the instant of puncture, so that spectators are left to infer something disagreeable. But in the 16 mm. film taken by [[Eastman Kodak|Kodak Ltd.]] in his own clinic the whole operation is photographed, and although now and then there may be a grimace or a hint of nervousness, there is certainly no crying or resistance. The children in the film, quite unrehearsed, behave perfectly. It is an excellent film and should do much to dispel parental apprehensions.” <ref>Immunization Propaganda. The British Medical Journal, Vol. 1, No. 3769 (Apr. 1, 1933), p. 573</ref>
In a 1935 issue of the [[British Medical Journal]], one could read the following advice regarding the use of films in public health: “If the medical profession wanted, for example, to introduce widespread [[Preventive healthcare|prophylaxis]] against [[diphtheria]] it could take a leaf out of Papworth's book and tell a story on the films that would help to wipe out diphtheria in a few years' time. It is no good trying to persuade people of the Tightness of this or that measure of health with the sweet voice of reason. It is the emotional appeal that wins the day; reason follows humbly after. The film, with its forcible assault upon both eye and ear, is a powerful weapon of propaganda. And it could be used with effect for ‘putting across’ to the public the idea of preventive medicine. Perhaps the Minister of Health, [[Sir Kingsley Wood]], a master of propaganda, might enlist the help of the moving picture in his campaign for the improved health of the people.” <ref>Papworth and Propaganda. The British Medical Journal, Vol. 2, No. 3911 (Dec. 21, 1935), pp. 1213-1214</ref>
==Contemporary cinematographic use in healthcare: healthcare knowledge transfer==
By the 1980s, medical films had become an established vehicle of both medical and patient training. A 1987 issue of the [http://journals.lww.com/AJNOnline/pages/default.aspx American Journal of Nursing] contained a full-page section on Films & Tapes covering broad topics such as Aids to Daily Living for the elderly, working moms, AIDS, alcohol abuse and even emotional fitness.<ref>Film listings. The American Journal of Nursing, Vol. 87, No. 12 (Dec., 1987), p. 1713</ref>
Today, the concept of '''healthcare knowledge transfer''' recognizes that film clips (with carefully crafted and verified content, and using graphics, animations and live-action video), can be one of the most efficient ways of transferring knowledge with clarity and speed, to both lay-people (patients, families, and friends), and healthcare professionals.
Traditionally the transfer of generic information (i.e. non patient-specific information) tends to happen on a somewhat ad-hoc, live, one-to-one basis, that is generally less well structured, less comprehensive, and thus less successful (whilst also being more expensive and less time efficient).
However, in order to be efficient and effective, the quality of the film’s content must be very high. A patient’s understanding of conditions and treatments is important to their care and well-being, so it is useful for carefully crafted clips to be available 24/7. It also helps patients when attending the all-important one-to-one consultations that are the bedrock of good healthcare. If patients are better informed and better prepared they can focus on their own case rather than generic issues.
The literature in this area also contains examples of what can happen when the film content is not particularly well crafted and presented. In 2000, a UK cancer study highlights the impact of poor quality video. The authors acknowledge that “not all [[Randomized controlled trials|randomised trials]] of video education, however, have had similarly consistent results. A randomised trial in patients undergoing [[colonoscopy]] reported increased knowledge and satisfaction but failed to demonstrate a reduction in anxiety. A similar study in patients receiving [[genetic counseling]] reported similar benefits but again no reduction in anxiety. Two further randomised trials, the first in patients having breast surgery and the second in patients undergoing [[coronary angioplasty]], failed to show any improvement in satisfaction or anxiety. The variation in these trial results suggests that, like all educational materials, the quality of the content is paramount and how it is used is vital to success. Involving patients in the development and showing patients recounting their personal experience undoubtedly helps. Using respected TV personalities offers the familiar face of respectability and professionalism. Above all, most studies fail to take advantage of the role which video has to play in continuing the educational process at home with their carers and friends, but instead ask patients to watch it in the unfamiliar environment of the clinic.” <ref>Thomas R et al. Forewarned is forearmed - benefits of preparatory information on video-cassette for patients receiving chemotherapy or radiotherapy - a randomised controlled trial. European Journal of cancer 36 (2000) 1536-1543).</ref>
With the widespread use of the internet since the late 1990s, there is a tremendous potential for health-related films to be made available, free at the point of need, over the internet. Moreover, the 21st century sees an expanding integration of [[social media]] and [[mobile devices]] into our lives, thus enabling an even wider adoption of film-based health knowledge transfer.
==Case studies of healthcare knowledge transfer via cinematography==
A recent slate of long-form films includes ‘Outreach’ - a film about the workings of a specialist spinal injury unit, [http://www.spinalinjury.tv The Spinal Injury Patient Film], an award-winning film for new patients with spinal cord injuries, [http://www.choosingawheelchair.com Choosing a Wheelchair], a film about the correct protocol of wheelchair assessment and procurement for individual patients, and several films on [[cancer survivorship]].
===[http://www.choosingawheelchair.com Choosing a wheelchair]: case study in the UK===
The 55 minute production is set to help improve well-being and long-term outcomes for Britain's 1.2 million wheelchair users. Too many people do not understand the importance of getting the right wheelchair; the right set-up and support, and the appropriate pressure relief. UK provision is patchy, indeed there is - surprisingly - no qualification requirement for a wheelchair services provider/specifier in the [[National Health Service]] (NHS).
The [http://www.choosingawheelchair.com film] includes leading experts and practitioners in this area, plus case studies, and even an introductory history of the wheelchair. It thus provides a comprehensive and holistic overview of best practice and assessment, and is supported by many voices of experience. For the NHS the long-term cost benefits of proper provision in an aging population are very considerable.
===[http://www.spinalinjury.tv Spinal injury patient film]===
Newly injured [[Spinal Cord Injury]] (SCI) patients are anxious about what is happening to them and the related long-term implications. When a patient is admitted to hospital with an SCI it is traumatic for their family, friends and loved ones too. One challenge faced by clinicians is communicating with a patient’s ‘advocates’, people who may know little of spinal cord injury, the care process, nor the problems of prognosis. They may be understandably overwhelmed, they want answers… “doctor, will he/she walk again?”.
Inspired by patient feedback, award-winning director [[Marcus Dillistone]], has created the film [http://www.spinalinjury.tv “From Darkness Into Light”], to help explain the core issues with SCI and to provide patient insight. The film is designed not to replace face-to-face discussion, but to complement it.
The [http://www.spinalinjury.tv film] was conceived as a ‘prescriptive’ communications tool in hospitals, with the decision of when (and if) to introduce the film to the patient or their advocates being made by the clinical team.
===Cancer survivorship films===
When a person is diagnosed with cancer, treatment is often the focus of discussion among patients, health care providers and family. However, the next phase of care, [[cancer survivorship]], is much less discussed. The 2005 [[Institute of Medicine]] (IOM) report “From Cancer Patient to Cancer Survivor: Lost in Transition” <ref>Institute of Medicine: From Cancer Patient to Cancer Survivor: Lost in Translation. 2005, National Academy Press: Washington, D.C.</ref> raised the awareness of the issue. Survivors of cancer face unique challenges, while health care providers do not always have the time, resource and training to provide counseling and assistance.
A 2005 randomized controlled study, Moving Beyond Cancer Trial,<ref>Stanton, A. L., et al., Outcomes from the Moving Beyond Cancer psychoeducational, randomized controlled trial with breast cancer patients. J Clin Oncol, 2005. 23(25): p. 6009-18.</ref> showed that a peer-modeling video as a psychoeducation tool is more effective than print materials in recovery of energy/vitality in post-treatment breast cancer patients. This 23-minute film, now available on the [http://www.cancer.gov/cancertopics/types/breast/beyond-cancer-video National Cancer Institute website], addressed re-entry challenges in four life domains: physical health, emotional well-being, interpersonal relations, and life perspectives. Designed to promote adaptive peer modeling, the film observes four breast cancer survivors as they describe their experience in each of the four domains, as well as active coping skills they used to meet associated challenges. The film also includes commentary by an oncologist expert in breast cancer on the re-entry experience and on active methods for approaching problems during re-entry.
Since then, many video resources have been made available on the internet to cancer survivors and their care providers. Examples include a general education video on the issues of cancer survivorship produced by the IOM, a video series by [[Living Beyond Breast Cancer]], a national education and support organization, addressing specific and sometimes sensitive issues during breast cancer survivorship.<ref name="Video">{{cite web|title=I Am a Young Woman With Breast Cancer|url=http://www.lbbc.org/Audiences/Young-Women/Let-s-Talk-About-It-Video-Series|website=Living Beyond Breast Cancer|accessdate=14 September 2016}}</ref>
==References== <references />
[[Category:Cinematography]] [[Category:Medical education]] [[Category:Public health education]]

'''CLIMIT - Programme for Power Generation with Carbon Capture and Storage.''' The programme is managed by [[Gassnova]] in cooperation with the [[Research Council of Norway]]. Responsibilities have been divided: whereas the Research Council of Norway is in charge of the research projects, Gassnova is responsible for the prototype and demonstration projects.
* CO<sub>2</sub> ([[carbon dioxide]]) before, during or after power production * Compression and handling of CO<sub>2</sub> * Transport of CO<sub>2</sub> * Long-term storage{{what?|date=April 2012}} of CO<sub>2</sub> and other areas of application
Gassnova shall focus on co-funding projects seen as having an obvious commercial potential and which include a market-oriented business plan. For research grants within the same field, please refer to the calls for proposals issued by the Research Council of Norway.
==References== {{Reflist}}
==External links== *[http://www.climit.no/?language=UK CLIMIT - Programme for Power Generation with Carbon Capture and Storage] *[http://www.gassnova.no/?language=UK Gassnova - Statens foretak for CO<sub>2</sub>-håndtering] *[https://web.archive.org/web/20090831000909/http://www.gassnova.no/co2-capture-storage/ CO<sub>2</sub> Capture & Storage]
